ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was an independent study so we had weekly one on one meetings and monthly group meetings (all over zoom or telephone call) with the other students doing independent studies with Prof Stillman.

I worked on my Independent Project with Professor Glck through the mail and over the phone. I would mail her new poems and revisions, and we would schedule a time to call and talk about the poems as she received them.
Verlyn and I met on Zoom every week.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Interviewing, reporting, research, long form article writing, analyzing and editing articles, pitching ideas

I learned how to write clearly and authoritatively about subjects that fascinate me, how to think through the process of writing an essay, and when to ignore the formalities of genre. I gained a greater sense of flexibility and freedom of expression.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: strengths: close relationship with professor and other students, lots of individualized support

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really liked the readings and weekly virtual meetings. I also thought it was helpful sending a weekly reporting memo. I think independent studies lend themselves well to virtual meetings -- gave us a lot of flexibility.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I improved so much in my resourcefulness, skills, and confidence. This was a great way to take what I've learned thus far and apply them to a different scenario with much more freedom.
Yes, I'd recommend this course to anyone who has a strong relationship with a professor and would like to further their craft.
Definitely do an independent study if you are able! I learned a lot about how I work best and got a lot of one-on-one attention which was great.

I did my tutorial in writing with Verlyn Klinkenborg. It's a wonderful experience to spend a semester working directly on an independent project, and meeting every week. I'm so glad I did it, and I'd recommend it to anyone!
